titleStmt.title: A diverse array of creatine kinase and arginine kinase isoform genes is present in the starlet sea anemone Nematostella vectensis, a cnidarian model system for studying developmental evolution

affiliation.orgName: Department of Biological Science and Institute of Molecular Biophysics

analytic.title: A diverse array of creatine kinase and arginine kinase isoform genes is present in the starlet sea anemone Nematostella vectensis, a cnidarian model system for studying developmental evolution

biblStruct.note: Accepted 19 January 2012

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Guanidino kinase Phosphagen kinase Arginine kinase Creatine kinase Nematostella vectensis AK, arginine kinase
RTPCR, reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction

abstract.p: Phosphagen (guanidino) kinases (PK) constitute a family of homologous phosphotransferases catalyzing the reversible transfer of the high-energy phosphoryl group of ATP to naturally occurring guanidine compounds. Prior work has shown that PKs can be phylogenetically separated into two distinct groups-an arginine kinase (AK) subfamily and a creatine kinase (CK) subfamily. The latter includes three CK isoforms-cytoplasmic CK (CyCK), mitochondrial CK (MiCK) and three-domain flagellar CK (fCK). In the present study we identified six unique PK genes from the draft genome sequence of the starlet sea anemone Nematostella vectensis, a wellknown model organism for understanding metazoan developmental evolution. Using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RTPCR) methods, full length cDNAs were amplified for all of these PKs. These cDNAs were cloned and expressed in Escherichia coli as 6x His-tagged fusion proteins. The six PKs were identified as the three typical CK isoforms (CyCK, MiCK and fCK), two unusual AKs (a two-domain AK (2DAK) and a threedomain AK (3DAK)) and a PK which phosphorylated arginine. The latter enzyme had a very low AK activity (its apparent V max value being less than 0.2% that of 3DAK), lacks several key residues necessary for AK enzyme activity, and was tentatively designated as AK1. As far as we know, this constitutes the first report of an AK with the three fused AK domains. The Bayesian tree suggested that the third domain of 3DAK likely evolved from the gene for domain 2 of typical two-domain AK found widely in cnidarians. Construction of phylogenetic trees and comparison of exon-intron organizations of their respective genes indicated that the N. vectensis three-domain fCK and 3DAK evolved independently, and both enzymes are likely to be targeted to cell membranes since they have a myristoylation signal at their respective N-termini. These results complement prior work on other basal invertebrates showing that multiple CK and AK isoform genes were present at the dawn of the radiation of metazoans. The presence of isoform diversity in an organism lacking in structural complexity reflects an early imperative for targeting of PKs to particular cellular contexts such as muscle fibers, neurons, ciliated/flagellated epithelia and spermatozoa.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Phosphagen (guanidino) kinases (PK) catalyze the reversible transfer of the high-energy phosphoryl group of ATP to naturally occurring guanidine compounds. Members of this enzyme family play a key role in animals as ATP-buffering systems in cells that display high and variable rates of ATP turnover (Ellington, 2001). The phosphorylated high-energy guanidines are referred to as phosphagens. In vertebrates, phosphocreatine is the only phosphagen, and the corresponding phosphagen kinase is creatine kinase (CK). In contrast, invertebrates have various phosphagens in addition to phosphocreatine: phosphoglycocyamine (catalyzed by glycocyamine kinase: GK), phosphotaurocyamine (taurocyamine kinase: TK), phosphohypotaurocyamine (hypotaurocyamine kinase: HTK), phospholombricine (lombricine kinase: LK) and phosphoarginine (arginine kinase: AK). Phosphagen kinases are phylogenetically separated into two distinct groups-the AK group (AK-supercluster) which includes AK and HTK, and the CK group (CK-supercluster) which includes CK, GK, LK and TK (Ellington and Suzuki, 2006;Uda et al., 2005a). Interestingly, several AKs, such as those from the echinoderm Stichopus and the annelid Sabellastarte, are clustered in the CK group indicating that they have evolved secondarily from CK-like genes (Suzuki et al., 1999;Uda and Suzuki, 2007).

In contrast to the relatively conserved exon/intron organization in the genes of the CK cluster (Suzuki et al., 2004;Tanaka et al., 2007a), those of the AK cluster seem to be highly divergent, suggesting that a frequent loss or gain of introns has occurred during the course of AK evolution (Uda et al., 2006). It should be noted that unusual 80 kDa AKs evolved independently at least four times: in protozoa, cnidarians, platyhelminths and heterodont clams (Uda et al., 2006). These enzymes have a two-domain structure, and are believed to result from gene duplication and subsequent fusion (Suzuki et al., 1997(Suzuki et al., , 1998.

There are three CK isoforms each targeted to different intracellular compartments. A cytoplasmic CK (CyCK) isoform exhibits a dimeric quaternary structure and is targeted to the cytoplasm (McLeish and Kenyon, 2005). A mitochondrial CK (MiCK) isoform is localized in the mitochondrial intermembrane space where it exists as both dimers and octamers with the octamer predominating under physiological conditions (Schlattner et al., 2006;Wyss et al., 1992). In addition, in certain deuterostome and protostome invertebrates, a third isoform called flagellar CK (fCK) is present Shapiro, 1987, 1989). This fCK is a contiguous trimer consisting of three, complete fused CK domains (Hoffman et al., 2008;Wothe et al., 1990) and is localized in the sperm flagellum via a myristate anchor (Quest et al., 1992). Moreover, the poriferans express the MiCK and protoflagellar CK (protofCK) that show great sequence similarity to a domain of the contiguous trimeric fCKs (Bertin et al., 2007;Sona et al., 2004). The information on intron/exon organization of all three CK isoforms suggested that the first duplication event producing the MiCK and protofCK genes as well as the second leading to CK isoform diversity occurred prior to the divergence of poriferans from the metazoan lineage (Bertin et al., 2007).

It is generally accepted that the CK lineage evolved from an AKlike ancestor via a gene duplication and divergence event, mainly based on the monomeric subunit structure of AK and unmodified structure of the substrate arginine as guanidino substrate. However, Hoffman and Ellington (2011) showed that several AKs from the choanoflagellate protozoan Monosiga (the closest protozoan relative of metazoans) are oligomeric, and suggested a close relationship of Monosiga sequences with those of CKs.

The starlet sea anemone Nematostella vectensis is a well-known model organism among cnidarians. The draft genome of the Nematostella has been sequenced and analyzed (Putnam et al., 2007). In this study, we extracted fragments of six phosphagen kinase genes from the draft genome database and determined their complete cDNA sequences by RT-PCR and RACE analysis. Six phosphagen kinases from Nematostella were identified as three typical CK isoforms (CyCK, MiCK and fCK), two unusual AKs (two-domain AK (2DAK) and three-domain AK (3DAK)) and a phosphagen kinase with very low AK activity (AK1). In addition, we assembled 18 new phosphagen kinase sequences from genomic and EST databases. We characterized the six Nematostella phosphagen kinases by phylogenetic analysis, comparison of gene structures and the determination of their enzyme activity.

div.head: Total RNA extraction and single-stranded cDNA synthesis
div.p: Live specimens of N. vectensis were obtained from Dr. Casey Dunn (Brown University, Providence, RI, USA). Animals were blotted on filter paper, weighed (0.5 g) and homogenized in 19.5 mL TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA). Total RNA was isolated according to the manufacturer's instructions and stored as an ethanol precipitate. Ethanol was removed from an aliquot of the total RNA sample which was then dissolved in RNAse-free water yielding 650 ng/μL. Single-stranded cDNA was synthesized using Ready To Go You Prime First Strand Beads (GE Healthcare, Piscataway, NJ, USA) in a reaction mixture consisting of 1 μL 0.5 μg/μL lock-docking oligo(dT) primer (Borson et al., 1992), μL total RNA and 30 μL RNAse-free water. The resulting single-stranded cDNA was reduced to dryness and shipped by air freight to Kochi University. A poly (G)+ tail was subsequently added to the 3′end of the Nematostella cDNA pool with terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (Promega, WI, USA).

div.head: Amplification (3′ and 5′ RACE) and sequence determination of phosphagen kinase cDNAs
div.p: The primers used for amplification of 5′ and 3′ cDNA ends were designed from the genomic sequences of six phosphagen kinase genes (three AKs and three CKs) searched from the N. vectensis genomic sequences from the trace archive in GenBank (http://www.ncbi. nlm.nih.gov/Traces/; Tables 1 and 2).

The 5′ and 3′-ends of the cDNA of phosphagen kinases were amplified using the oligo-dC primer (5′-GAATTC ) and a 5′-RACE outer primer (Table 1) or the oligo-dT primer (5′-CCCGGGATCCT VN) and a 3′-RACE outer primer (Table 1) with Ex Taq DNA polymerase (Takara, Kyoto, Japan) as the amplifying enzyme. PCR amplification was performed for 30 cycles, each consisting of denaturation for 30 s at 94°C, annealing for 30 s at 60°C and primer extension for 120 s at 72°C. The amplified products were re-amplified using the oligo-dC primer and a 5′-RACE inner primer (Table 1) or the oligo-dT primer and a 3′-RACE inner primer ( Table 1). The amplified products were purified by agarose gel electrophoresis and subcloned into the pGEM-T Easy Vector (Promega, WI, USA). Nucleotide sequences were determined with an ABI PRISM 3130 DNA sequencer using a BigDye Terminators v3.1 Cycle Sequencing Kit (Applied Biosystems, CA, USA).

div.head: Cloning into the pET30b plasmid and expression of Nematostella phosphagen kinases in E. coli
div.p: The open reading frame of Nematostella phosphagen kinases were amplified using two primers, a forward primer with an Nde I site and a reverse primer with 6x His-tag encoding sequence and a stop codon except for the 3DAK reverse primer which contained a Bam H I site, subcloned into the pGEM-T Easy Vector and sequenced using M13 and sequencing primers ( Table 1). The plasmid vectors were digested with Nde I and Eco RI and the Nematostella AK1, 2DAK, CyCK, MiCK and fCK fragments cloned into Nde I/Eco RI site of the pET30b vector (Novagen, WI, USA). The Nematostella 3DAK/pGEM plasmid was digested with Nde I and Bam HI and the cDNA fragment cloned into Nde I/Bam HI site of the pET30b vector. The pET30b plasmids were sequenced and confirmed that there was no intended mutation in the coding region of Nematostella phosphagen kinase cDNAs.

The fusion protein with a hexameric His tag at the C-terminal end was expressed in E. coli BL21(DE3) cells (Novagen, WI, USA) by induction with 0.5 mM IPTG at 25°C for 36 h. The cells were resuspended in lysis buffer (50 mM NaH PO 4 , 300 mM NaCl, pH 8.0) sonicated, and the resultant soluble recombinant protein was purified by affinity chromatography using Ni-NTA Superflow (QIAGEN, CA, USA). The purity of the expressed enzymes was verified by SDS-PAGE. The enzymes were placed on ice until use, and enzymatic activity was determined within 12 h.

div.head: Enzyme assays
div.p: Enzyme activity was measured using the NADH-linked spectrophotometric assay at 25°C (Fujimoto et al., 2005) and determined for the forward reaction (phosphagen synthesis). The reaction mixture (total volume of 1.0 ml) contained 0.65 ml of 100 mM Tris/HCl (pH 8), 0.05 ml of 750 mM KCl, 0.05 ml of 250 mM Mg-acetate, 0.05 ml of 25 mM phosphoenolpyruvate made up in 100 mM imidazole/HCl (pH 7), 0.05 ml of 5 mM NADH made up in 100 mM Tris/HCl (pH 8), 0.05 ml of pyruvate kinase/lactate dehydrogenase mixture made up in 100 mM imidazole/HCl (pH 7), 0.05 ml of 100 mM ATP made up in 100 mM imidazole/HCl (pH 7) and 0.05 ml of recombinant enzyme. The reaction was started by adding 0.05 ml of an appropriate concentration of arginine or creatine made up in 100 mM Tris/ HCl (pH 8). The initial velocity values were obtained by varying the concentration of one substrate (arginine or creatine) versus fixed concentration of the second substrate (ATP). The concentrations of the recombinant enzymes were estimated by the absorbance at 280 nm. The extinction coefficients at 280 nm in units of M − 1 cm − 1 were obtained using the computer program ProtParam available on the web site (http://ca.expasy.org/tools/protparam.html). To estimate kinetic constants, a Lineweaver-Burk plot was made and fitted by the leastsquare method using Microsoft Excel (Uda and Suzuki, 2007).

2.5. Search for cDNA and genome sequence of phosphagen kinases through available databases cDNAs and corresponding genome sequences were searched from genomic databases (Table 2) and the fragments coding phosphagen kinases sequence were assembled to yield a complete sequence. cDNAs and genomic sequences were aligned by using Spidey (http://www. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/IEB/Research/Ostell/Spidey/spideyweb.cgi).

div.head: Alignment of amino acid sequences of phosphagen kinases and construction of phylogenetic tree
div.p: Multiple sequence alignment of phosphagen kinases was done with the ClustalW program available on DDBJ homepage (http:// ddbj.nig.ac.jp/). The default setting was used for the alignment except that the PAM model was used to construct the distance matrix. The Neighbor-Joining (NJ) tree with bootstrap analysis (1000 replications) was also constructed with the program available on the DDBJ homepage (http://www.ddbj.nig.ac.jp/) using default setting. The Bayesian tree was constructed with MrBayes 3.1.2 program (Ronquist and Huelsenbeck, 2003).

div.head: cDNA and deduced amino acid sequences of Nematostella phosphagen kinases
div.p: We extracted fragments of six phosphagen kinase genes from N. vectensis genomic sequences from the trace archive in GenBank. Using these sequences, the complete cDNA sequences were amplified by RT-PCR and RACE analysis (Table 2). Those six cDNA sequences were identified as a cytoplasmic CK (CyCK), a mitochondrial CK (MiCK), a three-domain flagellar CK (fCK), a two-domain AK (2DAK), a threedomain AK (3DAK) and a phosphagen kinase (tentatively assigned as AK1), respectively. These sequences were submitted to the DDBJ (Table 2).

The cDNA for the CyCK consists of 1346 bp with an ORF of 1131 bp and 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions of 45 and 170 bp, respectively. The Table 1 Primers used for the amplification of 5′ and 3′ cDNA ends, sequencing and cloning of the phosphagen kinases from Nematostella vectensis.

div.head: Primer name
div.p: Sequence ( ORF codes for a protein containing 376 amino acid residues with a calculated molecular mass of 42116.9 Da and an estimated pI of 5.76. The cDNA for the MiCK consists of 1440 bp with an ORF of 1236 bp and 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions of 33 and bp, respectively. The ORF codes for a protein containing amino acid residues with a calculated molecular mass of 45794.0 Da and an estimated pI of 8.15. The deduced amino acid sequence of MiCK has a long N-terminal extension of 40 amino acid residues, compared to the CyCK (Fig. 1). Analysis of this region using the SignalP 3.0 Server (http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/ SignalP/) revealed a high probability as a mitochondrial targeting sequence. The cDNA for the fCK consists of 3875 bp with an ORF of bp and 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions of 24 and 374 bp, respectively. The ORF codes for a protein containing 1081 amino acid residues with a calculated molecular mass of 129219.1 Da and an estimated pI of 7.74. The deduced amino acid sequence of fCK has an N-terminal extension of 13 amino acid residues, compared to the CyCK (Fig. 3).
The sequences of each domains of fCK showed 72-80% amino acid identity with each other. On the other hand, each of the domains showed a lower degree of identity (64-72%) with CyCK or MiCK.

The cDNA for the AK1 consists of 1379 bp with an ORF of 1191 bp and 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions of 20 and 168 bp, respectively. The ORF codes for a protein containing 396 amino acid residues with a calculated molecular mass of 44346.4 Da and an estimated pI of 5.67. The cDNA for the unusual 2DAK consists of 2520 bp with an ORF of 2145 bp and 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions of 162 and 213 bp, respectively. The ORF codes for a protein containing 714 amino acid residues with a calculated molecular mass of 80169.1 Da and an estimated pI of 7.56. The cDNA for the unusual 3DAK consists of 3570 bp with an ORF of 3246 bp and 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions of 41 and 283 bp, respectively. The ORF codes for a protein containing 1081 amino acid residues with a calculated molecular mass of 121402.5 Da and an estimated pI of 5.80.

The sequences of each domains of Nematostella 2DAK showed 78% amino acid identity with each other. Similarly, the sequences of each domains of Nematostella 3DAK showed 80-84% amino acid identity with each other. However, the domains of 2DAK or 3DAK showed rather lower degree of identity (38-43%) with the AK1.

The N-terminal amino acid sequences of all the six phosphagen kinases from Nematostella were analyzed using the NMT N-terminal myristoylation prediction site (http://mendel.imp.univie.ac.at/myristate/ SUPLpredictor.htm). Among these, Nematostella fCK and 3DAK were identified to have a clear-cut myristoylation consensus sequence (GLFPSKRGSKSKSASSD for 3DAK and GCGASKTTATVKGVKVK for fCK), suggesting that these proteins have a potential for myristoylation and targeting to cellular membranes like the fCKs from sea urchin Strongylocentrotus purpuratus (Quest et al., 1992) and polychaete Chaetopterus variopedatus (Suzuki et al., 2004).

div.head: Alignment of amino acid sequences of Nematostella phosphagen kinases
div.p: Amino acid sequences of Nematostella CyCK, MiCK and fCK were aligned with that of Torpedo CK (Fig. 1), whose transition state analog complex (TSAC) structure has been determined and the substratebinding sites for the creatine and ATP are known (Lahiri et al., 2002). In the TSAC structures of Torpedo CK and human brain-type CK (Bong et al., 2008), three residues (V62, E232 and C283; indicated by '*' in Fig. 1) and five Arg residues (R130, R132, R2236, R292 and R320; indicated by '#' in Fig. 1) interact with creatine and ADP, respectively. These eight residues have been strictly conserved in all CK isoforms of Nematostella (Fig. 1).

Amino acid sequences of Nematostella AK1 and domains of 2DAK and 3DAK were aligned with that of Limulus AK (Fig. 2), whose TSAC structure has been determined and the substrate-binding sites for the arginine and ATP are known (Yousef et al., 2003;Zhou et al., 1998). In the Limulus AK TSAC structure, seven residues (S63, G64, V65, Y68, E225, C271 and E314; indicated by '*' in Fig. 2) and five Arg residues (R124, R126, R229, R280 and R309; indicated by '#' in Fig. 2) interact with arginine and ADP, respectively (Zhou et al., 1998). Moreover, these residues are strictly conserved among typical AKs, except for the residues positioned at 64 or 65, which are somewhat variable (Iwanami et al., 2009). Comparison of the amino acid sequences of Limulus AK and Nematostella AKs indicated that the five residues (S63, Y68, E225, C271 and E314) interacting with arginine were conserved in all domains of Nematostella 2DAK and 3DAK, but in Nematostella AK1 two residues at positions 68 and 225 were unusually substituted for by His and Gly, respectively (Fig. 2). In contrast, the five Arg residues interacting with ADP were conserved in all of Nematostella AKs (Fig. 2). The D62 and R193 residues (indicated by '$' in The D62 and R193 residues have been conserved in all domains of Nematostella 2DAK and 3DAK, but these residues were substituted for by Thr and Lys, respectively, in Nematostella AK1 (Fig. 2). Thus, the AK1 sequence appears to be rather divergent, compared with a typical AK, suggesting that the main target for the guanidino substrate is not an arginine in Nematostella AK1. The predicted myristoylation consensus sequence in Nematostella fCK is underlined. The residues that interact with creatine and ADP in the Torpedo CK crystal structure (Lahiri et al., 2002) are indicated by '*' and '#', respectively. The guanidino substrate-specific residue (Edmiston et al., 2001;Tanaka and Suzuki, 2004) is indicated by '%'.

Amino acid residue 89 (indicated by '%' in Figs. 1 and 2) has been proposed to be one of the key residues for recognition of guanidino substrates in phosphagen kinases (Edmiston et al., 2001;Tanaka and Suzuki, 2004). Multiple alignments of amino acid sequences clearly indicated that the residue is strictly conserved as a specific amino acid in each phosphagen kinase: R in CK (see Fig. 1, indicated by '%'), Y in typical AKs, I in GK, H in TK, and K in LK (Ellington and Suzuki, 2006). While this residue does not appear to be directly involved in substrate binding in the TSAC structures of CK and AK, it is located close to the guanidine substrate-binding site (Bong et al., 2008;Lahiri et al., 2002;Zhou et al., 1998). Site-directed mutagenesis studies of this residue in rabbit CK and Einenia LK have shown that it had a significant impact on enzymatic activity and guanidino substrate specificity (Edmiston et al., 2001;Tanaka and Suzuki, 2004). A recent report investigating Danio CK showed that the residue-89 plays a key role in organizing the hydrogen bond network between Fig. 2. Alignment of amino acid sequences of AKs. The predicted myristoylation consensus sequence in Nematostella 3DAK is underlined. Arginine-and ADP-binding residues in Limulus AK crystal structure (Zhou et al., 1998) are indicated by '*' and '#', respectively; highly conserved residues D62 and R193 (Suzuki et al., 2000a) are indicated by '$'; and guanidino substrate-specific residues (Edmiston et al., 2001;Tanaka and Suzuki, 2004) are indicated by '%'.

the four dynamic domains (Yousef et al., 2003) of AK and CK, thereby providing an appropriate active center for high catalytic turnover (Uda et al., 2009). In Nematostella three CKs and three AKs, the 89th residues are conserved as R (CK-specific residue) and Y (AK-specific residue), respectively (Figs. 1 and 2).

div.head: Phylogenetic trees for amino acid sequences of phosphagen kinases
div.p: Phylogenetic trees were constructed from the amino acid sequences of 88 phosphagen kinases by the neighbor-joining (NJ) and Bayes methods (Figs. 3a and b, respectively). The sequences include eight Nematostella phosphagen kinases (additional two PKs are described in Section 3.6.) and 19 newly assembled sequences in this work (5 from arthropods, 1 from a chordate, 3 from cnidarians, 2 from echinoderms, 2 from mollusks, 3 from nematodes, 1 from a platyhelminth and 2 from poriferans (see Table 2)). Similar topology was obtained with the method of maximum-likelihood (PHYLIP 3.69; data not shown). The topologies in Figs. 3a and b are very similar to that of a previous tree constructed using 148 sequences of phosphagen kinases (Uda et A Fig. 3. Phylogenetic trees for the amino acid sequences of 85 phosphagen kinases. (A) The Neighbor-joining (NJ) tree was constructed using the program available on the DDBJ homepage (http://www.ddbj.nig.ac.jp/). (B) The Bayesian tree was constructed using the program MrBayes 3.1.2 (Ronquist and Huelsenbeck, 2003). The NJ bootstrap and Bayesian posterior probability values are shown at the branching point. Accession numbers of the sequences are listed in Table 2. Nematostella phosphagen kinases are underlined, and the newly assembled sequences are marked by asterisks. The stars indicate occurrence of gene duplication and subsequent fusion events in the AK genes. al., 2005a). The trees in Figs. 3a and b separate phosphagen kinases into two distinct lineages, a CK-supercluster which includes the three CK isoforms (CyCK, MiCK and fCK), echinoderm AKs, and annelid-specific enzymes (MiTK, MiLK, GK, LK, and Sabellastarte AK), and an AK-supercluster which includes invertebrate, ciliate and a choanoflagellate AK and platyhelminth TKs.

In the AK-supercluster, Nematostella 2DAK and 3DAK are grouped with the cnidarian AKs, including two-domain sequences from Anthopleura (Suzuki et al., 1997), Acropora (domain 1 and 2, assembled in this work), Aiptasia (domain 1, assembled in this work) and Metridium (domain 2). It should be noted that all sequences from cnidarians obtained thus far include poly-domain AKs, suggesting that AK gene duplication events occurred at an early time of cnidarian evolution.

The gene duplication processes of AK domains to form two-or three-domain enzymes are not clear from the branching pattern of the NJ tree (Fig. 3a). However, the Bayesian tree solves this problem: the tree (Fig. 3b) separated clearly all the cnidarian AK domains into two groups; one group including domain 1 only, and the other group including domain 2 and 3. This suggests that the domain 3 of Nematostella 3DAK evolved from the lineage of gene for domain 2. In fact, the domain of Nematostella 3DAK shows higher amino acid sequence identity with domain 2 of Nematostella 2DAK and 3DAK (84-86%) than with domain (79-80%).

As far as we know, there is no precedent for a three-domain AK, and the Nematostella 3DAK is the first report for this. As can be clearly seen in the phylogenetic tree (Fig. 3), it is evident that the B Fig. 3 (continued).
Nematostella 3DAK in the AK-supercluster and fCK (three-domain CK) in the CK-supercluster evolved independently. More interestingly, both N-termini of these proteins are likely to be myristoylated.

The phylogenetic position of two cnidarian AKs, Nematostella AK1 and Aiptasia AK1, is rather remote from the cluster of cnidarian 2DAKs and 3DAK, and they are surprisingly grouped with the AKs from the ciliate Tetrahymena (Fig. 3). This is not inconsistent with the idea that Nematostella AK1 might have a specificity towards unknown guanidino substrates as described above.

Previously, we pointed out that in the AK-supercluster, gene duplication and subsequent fusion events forming two-domain AKs or TKs occurred independently in at least four phyla (indicated by stars in Fig. 3) in Protozoa (Tetrahymena), Cnidaria (Anthopleura), Platyhelminthes (Schistosoma and Paragonimus) and Mollusca (Solen, Corbicula, Ensis, Pseudocardium and Calyptogena) (Jarilla et al., 2009;Uda et al., 2006Uda et al., , 2008. Interestingly, two-domain AKs occurred twice independently in the molluscan cluster: in bivalves (Preusocardium) and in gastropods (Lottia) (see Fig. 3).

In the CK-supercluster, the three CK isoforms (cytoplasmic, mitochondrial and flagellar) did not form distinct, isoform-specific clusters in the NJ and Bayesian trees (Fig. 3), like those obtained in ML trees using 56 or 45 CK sequences (Bertin et al., 2007;Suzuki et al., 2004). However, comparisons of the gene structures have shown that the three CK isoform genes each have unique isoform-specific features in terms of exon-intron organization (Suzuki et al., 2004).

div.head: Gene sequences and exon/intron organization for phosphagen kinases
div.p: The exon/intron organization of the six phosphagen kinases from Nematostella was deduced by comparisons of the cDNA (this work) and genomic sequences (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Traces/). A comparison of the exon/intron organization of 78 phosphagen kinase genes, 29 of which are derived from domain 1 (D1), domain 2 (D2) or domain 3 (D3) of two-or three-domain enzymes, is shown in Figs. 4a (AK genes) and b (CK genes). In the figure, we identified 92 unique positions of introns which are indicated by the amino acid position number in the alignment of 78 phosphagen kinase sequences (data not shown) and phase (0, 1 or 2). Of the 92 intron positions, 40 are in phase 0 (43%), 30 are in phase 1 (33%) and 22 are in phase 3 (24%). The phase bias of PK genes is similar to usual eukaryotic intron phase bias with the ratio of 5:3:2 for phases 0, 1 and 2 (χ 2 = 1.7 with 2 df, P > 0.05) (Qiu et al., 2004). It is thought that intron insertion events occur at consensus proto-splice sites (AG/GT) (Da Lage et al., 2011;Dibb, 1991). Among 369 introns of 78 PK genes, 64 proto-splice site sequences (AG/gt…intron…ag/GT) were found (Fig. 4). Thus, some sharing intron positions were possibly the result of parallel gain of introns.

These analyses showed that 48 positions of the introns are conserved in more than one gene, while 44 positions are unique and exist in only one gene. Two intron positions, 109.1 and 327.0, are generally conserved in most of the phosphagen kinase groups. The former intron is conserved in cnidarian, molluscan, arthropod and nematode AKs, platyhelminth TKs, protoflagellar CK and flagellar CKs. In cytoplasmic and flagellar CKs and echinoderm AKs, a sliding of the intron 109.1 to 114.1 appears to have occurred. Intron 327.0 is conserved in molluscan and arthropod AKs, platyhelminth TKs, cytoplasmic, mitochondrial and flagellar CKs, echinoderm AKs and annelid PKs. These two conserved introns (109.1/114.1 and 327.0) support the hypothesis that all phosphagen kinases evolved from a common ancestral gene which had the two introns. On the other hand, Tetrahymena (Ciliophora, Protozoa) AKs do not share these two conserved introns. This may be due to the large evolutionary distance between protozoans and metazoans. Nevertheless, the key amino acid residues necessary for the enzyme activity are highly conserved among all AKs including Tetrahymena AKs (Uda et al., 2006).
The gene for Nematostella AK1 has only one intron at position 109.1 which is one of the highly conserved as described above. On the other hand, the genes for 3DAK and 2DAK lack this intron.

The Nematostella 3DAK gene has three introns (45.2, 56.2 and 213.0) in domain 1, three introns (125.1, 213.0 and 263.1) in domain 2 and one intron (281.1) in domain 3, in addition to two bridge introns (indicated by BI in the Figs. 4a and b) that separate the three domains. The Nematostella 2DAK gene has four introns (56.2, 125.1, 213.0 and 281.1) in domain 1 and three introns (125.1, 213.0 and 263.1) in domain 2, in addition to one bridge intron. The introns at positions 125.1 and 213.0 are conserved widely in domains of cnidarian 2DAK and 3DAK, suggesting that theses domains are evolved from common ancestral gene. As suggested by the Bayesian tree analysis (Fig. 3b), the domain 3 of Nematostella 3DAK is likely to be derived from gene for its domain 2. However, the exon/intron organization of Nematostella domain 2 (intron positions: 125.1, 213.0 and 263.1) is quite different from that of domain 3 (intron position: 281.1; this intron is conserved in domain 1). It appears that the origin of the target gene cannot be fully deduced from the exon/intron organization of the genes of these multi-domanin proteins.

In the ecdysozoa, we assembled and determined the AK gene structures from five arthropods and three nematodes. Previously, we suggested that the intron positions are highly divergent in the arthropods and nematodes AK genes, compared with molluscan AKs (Uda et al., 2006). However, surprisingly, the intron positions of the AK gene from the arachnid Tetranychus (109.1, 205.0, 265.2 and 327.0), assembled in this work, were the same as those in molluscan AKs. This indicates clearly that AK genes of arthropods, molluscs and nematodes evolved from a common, immediate ancestor. Tetranychus AK is grouped unambiguously in the arthropod AK cluster in NJ and Bayesian trees (Fig. 3).

The gene for Nematostella CyCK has two introns at position 114.1 and 227.0, one of which (114.1) corresponds to the highly conserved intron in cytoplasmic CKs. Domains 1, 2 and 3 of Nematostella fCK gene have four (61.0, 227.1, 335.1 and 427.0), no and one (227.1) introns, respectively. Among them two (227.1 and 335.1) are same as for the poriferan protofCKs, supporting the close relationship between protofCK and fCK. It is noteworthy that the Nematostella fCK has no bridge introns that usually separate the domains of multidomain proteins (Suzuki and Yamamoto, 2000;Suzuki et al., 1997). This is in sharp contrast to the Nematostella 3DAK which has two bridge introns. The gene of Nematostella MiCK has two introns at position 222.2 and 375.0, the later one is strictly conserved intron in MiCKs and annelid PKs except for Eisenia LK.

Overall, the above observations of the intron/exon organization of the phosphagen kinase genes from Nematostella, when viewed in the context of the organization of genes from other groups, provide insights into many aspect of the evolution of AK and CK gene families.

div.head: Enzyme activity of Nematostella phosphagen kinases
div.p: The six phosphagen kinases from Nematostella were successfully expressed as soluble proteins with 6 x His-tag, and purified by affinity chromatography. The preliminary kinetic constants for guanidino substrates were obtained from the Lineweaver-Burk plot in the presence of 4.76 mM ATP, and the results are summarized with those of AKs and CKs from other sources ( Table 3).

The values for apparent K m arg (0.213 and 0.317 mM), apparent V max (278 and 176 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 ) and V max /K m arg (1310 and 555 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 mM − 1 ) from Nematostella 2DAK and 3DAK, respectively, are in the range found for other AKs: 0.12-1.44 mM for apparent K m arg , 1.95-508.5 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 for apparent V max and 3.00-1820 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 mM − 1 for V max /K m arg (Table 3). On the other hand, the values 19.8 mM, 0.278 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 and 0.0140 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 mM − 1 , respectively, for Nematostella AK1 are completely out of this range indicating the enzyme has much lower substrate affinity and enzyme activity for arginine (Table 3). The AK1 showed low activity but retained more than 95% activity when incubating at 4°C for 24 h or at 25°C for 2 h. As discussed above, the six highly conserved key residues (see Fig. 2; D62, G64, V65, Y68, R193, and E225 in Limulus AK) involved in substrate arginine binding and stabilization of the substrate-bound structure, are not conserved in Nematostella AK1. These results raise the possibility that the main target for the guanidino substrate of Nematostella AK1 may not be arginine. However, the AK1 did not show any detectable activity for the other naturally occurring guanidino compounds Fig. 4. Comparison of the gene structures (exon/intron organization) of phosphagen kinases. The positions of introns are based on the amino acid sequences alignment (data not shown). Intron phases are indicated by '0', '1' or '2' in the boxes. Bridge intron (BI) separates the two or three domains of 2DAK, 3DAK or fCK. Closed boxes indicate that the intronexon junctions contain proto-splicing sequence (AG/gt…intron…ag/GT). (a) for AK genes, and (b) for CK genes. (Ellington, 2001;Hiramatsu, 2003;Makisumi, 1961), D-arginine, agmatine, β-guanidinopropionic acid, γ-guanidinobutyric acid, homoarginine, methylguanidine, creatine, glycocyamine and taurocyamine.

The kinetic constants of apparent K m Cr , V max and V max /K m Cr of Nematostella CyCK (26.0 mM, 75.5 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 and 2.90 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 mM − 1 , respectively) and MiCK (11.4 mM, 83.7 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 and 7.34 μmol min − 1 mg − 1 mM − 1 , respectively) are similar to those of other CyCKs and MiCKs (Table 3). In protofCK and fCK, the kinetic constants for the forward reaction were reported only for Strongylocentrotus fCK (Tombes and Shapiro, 1987). The V max value of Nematostella fCK is similar to that of Strongylocentrotus fCK, while there are about five-fold differences in the apparent K m Cr and V max /K m Cr values between these fCKs. However, the values for Nematostella fCK are in the range found for CyCKs and MiCKs. Thus all the three Nematostella CK forms are active and behave as typical CK isoforms.

div.head: Multiple phosphagen kinases system in Nematostella
div.p: Occurrence of more than one phosphagen (and its corresponding phosphagen kinase) in an animal was first described by Needham et al. (1932), and three decades later, Robin (1964) defined this as the "pluriphosphagen" phenomenon. The occurrence of more than one phosphagen in an animal is widely observed in polychaetes (Robin, 1964), echinoderms (Ratto et al., 1989) and tunicates (Watts, 1975). The recent sequence analyses showed clearly the presence of two genes for phosphagen kinases with different guanidino substrate specificity in the tropical marine worm Namalycastis sp. (GK and CK) and the polychaete Neanthes diversicolor (GK and CK) (Mizuta et al., 2005). However these enzymes, GK and MiCK, are derived from the CK-supercluster in the phylogenetic tree (see Fig. 3).

Virtually all animals typically express phosphagen kinase genes belonging either to the CK-supercluster or to the AK-supercluster. Accumulated evidence would suggest that the AK-supercluster genes have been lost in the species of the phyla Brachiopoda, Hemichordata, Echinodermata and Chordata, while CK-supercluster genes were lost in the other phyla. In fact, only AK-or CK-supercluster genes have been identified in Ciona intestinalis, Drosophila melanogaster and Caenorhabditis elegans, whose genome sequences have been entirely completed. However in this work, we showed that at least six phosphagen kinases are expressed in Nematostella, three (CyCK, MiCK and fCK) of which are included in the CK-supercluster and three (2DAK, 3DAK and AK1) are in the AK-supercluster (Fig. 3). Moreover, we identified additional two CK genes (CK4 and CK5) from the N. vectensis Whole Genome Shotgun (WGS) BLAST program (http://blast. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi?PROGRAM=blastn&BLAST_SPEC=WGS& BLAST_PROGRAMS=megaBlast&PAGE_TYPE=BlastSearch). The two CKs are clustered with MiCK group in phylogenetic trees (Fig. 3). On the other hand, these CK sequences were not found in N. vectensis EST sequences from GenBank (~160,000 records) or Trace Archive (~140,000 records). Therefore, it is suggested that these CK genes were not or very weakly expressed in N. vectensis. Thus, it is evident that at least at an early stage of phosphagen kinase evolution as in cnidarians, two types of genes (AK-and CK-supercluster genes) had been conserved.

The presence of three CK isoforms and three AK isoforms in a basal metazoan such as N. vectensis might be construed as surprising given the lack of complexity of structure in sea anemones and other cnidarians. Both CK and AK are typically found in cells which display high and variable rates of ATP turnover and/or those that have polarized morphology in which there is large separation between ATP "source" (mitochondria) and ATP "sink" (peripheral ATPases) (Ellington, 2001;Meyer et al., 1984). This latter role of phosphagen kinases in "spatial ATP buffering" is facilitated by the presence of isoforms targeted to Table 3 Comparison of kinetic constants of AKs and CKs for the forward reaction (phosphagen synthesis). specific intracellular compartments as is the case of the three types of CKs (Wallimann et al., 1992).

In spite of their relative simplicity, sea anemones like N. vectensis possess a variety of cell types which fulfill the functional criteria for likely expression of PKs. These include the possession of neurons, muscle fibers and ciliated/flagellated epi-and endothelial cell layers (Williams, 1975). Furthermore, this species has unique, flagellated structures of unknown function called nematosomes which are motile and circulate in the coelenteron space (Williams, 1975;1979). N. vectensis is dioecious and produces primitive-type spermatozoa (Frank and Bleakney, 1976). While detailed, cellular localization studies would be required to provide definitive answers as to where the CK and AK isoforms are expressed in this species, several lines of information point to possibilities. Primitive-type spermatozoa, which are highly polarized in structure, typically express AK or CK, and in the case of CK containing sperm the full suite of isoforms (for instance see Tombes and Shapiro, 1989). The spermatozoa of sea anemone Calliactis parasitica contain significant amounts of creatine while it is lacking in the muscle of this species (Roche et al., 1957). Thus, it is likely that the three CK isoforms are expressed in the spermatozoa of N. vectensis. Furthermore, the presence of a myristoylation peptide on the three domain AK of this species might indicate that it is targeted to the cilia/flagella of the epi-and endothelial cells as well as the nematosomes.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 2) are conserved in most AK sequences including Stichopus AK, which evolved secondarily from a CK gene and are suggested to play a key role in stabilizing the substrate-bound structure by forming an ion pair(Fujimoto et al., 2005;Suzuki et al., 2000b;Uda and Suzuki, 2004).

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: We thank Dr. Casey Dunn (Brown University, Providence, RI, USA) for providing live specimens of N. vectensis for use in this study. We thank an anonymous reviewer who suggested that additional two PKs exist in the genome. This work was supported by a Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research in Japan to KU (21770080) and to TS (17570062 and 20570072) and a grant from the U.S. National Science Foundation to WRE (IOB-0542236).
